elements.content: Lanthanide-containing benzoquinoid-type frameworks have been of significant interest due to their potential for application in high-density information storage and processing, photoluminescence, and sensing. With physical and chemical properties linked to the dimensionality of coordination polymers, control of network topology is desirable in generating targeted materials. The use of various cations as templates in the synthesis of Ce­(III) and Er­(III) frameworks has been investigated in this study. 2D (6,3) sheets of composition [M2(can)3(H2O)6]·solvate (M = Ce or Er, can = chloranilate) are formed with the tetraalkylammonium cations, tetramethylammonium or tetrabutylammonium. When the aromatic cation 1-(diphenylmethyl)-pyridinium (DPMP+) is incorporated in the reaction mixture, anionic diamond-type networks of composition [M­(can)2]− (M = Ce or Er) are formed, with the cation occupying adamantane-type cavities. The use of tetraphenylphosphonium also yields a diamond-like network but only in the case of [Ce­(can)2]−. When methyltriphenylphosphonium is employed, 3D anionic networks with unusual connectivity are obtained.
elements.clean_text: Lanthanide-containing benzoquinoid-type frameworks have been of significant interest due to their potential for application in high-density information storage and processing, photoluminescence, and sensing. With physical and chemical properties linked to the dimensionality of coordination polymers, control of network topology is desirable in generating targeted materials. The use of various cations as templates in the synthesis of Ce(III) and Er(III) frameworks has been investigated in this study. 2D (6,3) sheets of composition [M2(can)3(H2O)6]⋅solvate (M = Ce or Er, can = chloranilate) are formed with the tetraalkylammonium cations, tetramethylammonium or tetrabutylammonium. When the aromatic cation 1-(diphenylmethyl)-pyridinium (DPMP+) is incorporated in the reaction mixture, anionic diamond-type networks of composition [M(can)2]- (M = Ce or Er) are formed, with the cation occupying adamantane-type cavities. The use of tetraphenylphosphonium also yields a diamond-like network but only in the case of [Ce(can)2]-. When methyltriphenylphosphonium is employed, 3D anionic networks with unusual connectivity are obtained.

elements.content: The effect of the countercation size and shape on the topology of Ce­(III) and Er­(III) chloranilate frameworks was investigated. The use of alkylammonium cations resulted in exclusively 2D (6,3) honeycomb, whereas the use of PPh4 + and DPMP+ yielded 3D diamond nets. The use of PPh3Me+ gave unusual (4,4)-c topologies.
elements.clean_text: The effect of the countercation size and shape on the topology of Ce(III) and Er(III) chloranilate frameworks was investigated. The use of alkylammonium cations resulted in exclusively 2D (6,3) honeycomb, whereas the use of PPh4 + and DPMP+ yielded 3D diamond nets. The use of PPh3Me+ gave unusual (4,4)-c topologies.

elements.content: The field of coordination frameworks has been of significant interest due to the huge potential that they offer with respect to a vast range of applications including gas storage and separation, biomedical uses, and chemical sensing. The numerous combinations of metals and ligands afford a toolbox for assembling a coordination framework with the desired properties for various applications. Whereas some properties of coordination frameworks are imparted by the ligand (e.g., containing redox-active, light-active, or other stimuli-responsive groups) combined with those of the metal (e.g., paramagnetic, diamagnetic, redox-active), many of the properties exhibited by coordination frameworks are a result of their supramolecular structure. A large focus has been on exploiting the pores within coordination frameworks, as exemplified by their use in gas storage and separation, in drug delivery, and for the X-ray analysis of species that are difficult to crystallize. Control over the topology of a framework is therefore important as the size and shape of the pores, the presence and/or the extent of interpenetration, as well as the intermolecular interactions between adjacent ligands and guests will impact the resultant properties of the material.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The field of coordination frameworks has been of significant interest due to the huge potential that they offer with respect to a vast range of applications including gas storage and separation, biomedical uses, and chemical sensing.  The numerous combinations of metals and ligands afford a toolbox for assembling a coordination framework with the desired properties for various applications. Whereas some properties of coordination frameworks are imparted by the ligand (e.g., containing redox-active, light-active, or other stimuli-responsive groups) combined with those of the metal (e.g., paramagnetic, diamagnetic, redox-active), many of the properties exhibited by coordination frameworks are a result of their supramolecular structure. A large focus has been on exploiting the pores within coordination frameworks, as exemplified by their use in gas storage and separation, in drug delivery, and for the X-ray analysis of species that are difficult to crystallize. Control over the topology of a framework is therefore important as the size and shape of the pores, the presence and/or the extent of interpenetration, as well as the intermolecular interactions between adjacent ligands and guests will impact the resultant properties of the material.

elements.content: A multitude of structures with benzoquinoid-type ligands and transition-metal ions have been reported with a variety of topologies including 1D zigzag chains, 2D (6,3) sheets, and 3D (10,3)-a structures. Of particular note is the dominance of two topologies: 2D (6,3) structures and 3D (10,3)-a structures. The use of lanthanide ions in combination with benzoquinoid-type ligands should yield a larger variety of topologies due to the larger lanthanide ion accommodating higher coordination numbers. A more limited number of studies have been conducted to date using lanthanide ions and benzoquinoid-type ligands. The topology of lanthanide benzoquinoid frameworks is dominated by neutral 2D (6,3) nets, often with some distortion in a longitudinal, latitudinal, or diagonal manner away from a regular hexagonal net. In all of these (6,3) nets, three benzoquinoid ligands are coordinated to the lanthanide center, with the remaining coordination sphere composed of either two or three coordinated solvent molecules, dependent on whether the lanthanide center is eight or nine coordinate.

elements.content: Three main redox states can be accessed electrochemically and through the chemical reduction of the deprotonated benzoquinoid ligand: the quinoid (2−), the radical semiquinoid (3−), and the catecholate (4−) states. A large surge of interest in benzoquinoid frameworks has occurred in the last 3 to 4 years due to the demonstration that the radical semiquinoid (3−) ligand can mediate magnetic and electronic coupling between adjacent metal centers. The strong magnetic and electronic coupling is exemplified in Fe­(II)/Fe­(III) chloranilate- (can2–) and dihydroxybenzoquinone- (dhbq2–) containing frameworks due to the presence of an intervalence charge transfer (IVCT) process. The ligand-centered radical mediated electronic coupling in the 3D (10,3)-a (NBu4)2[Fe­(III)2(dhbq)3] framework resulted in a conductivity of 0.16 ± 0.01 S cm–1 at 298 K, which is one of the highest values for porous coordination frameworks. The 2D (6,3) honeycomb framework, (Me2NH2)2[Fe2(can)3]·2H2O·6DMF, exhibited an impressive magnetic ordering temperature (T c) of 105 K, one of the highest to date for a porous material.

elements.content: The unique optical and magnetic properties afforded by lanthanide ions in combination with the radical semiquinoid (3−) ligand may yield interesting materials for electro-optical, data storage, and sensing applications. Control over the supramolecular structure in these cases is particularly important, given that even small changes in the coordination sphere of the metal and solvent interactions in the pore can have a large effect on the bulk properties of the material. The distortion in lanthanide anilato-based 2D (6,3) honeycomb sheets has been shown to be affected by both the size of the lanthanide ion as well as the size, shape, and chemical nature of the solvent used. Recently, lanthanide benzoquinoid frameworks with an anionic 2D square grid (4,4) net synthesized in the presence of a tetraethylammonium cation was reported with a wide range of lanthanide metal centers. These square grid networks comprised four ligands coordinated to a lanthanide ion to yield an eight-coordinate metal center. The tetraethylammonium cation was located directly between lanthanide centers in distinct 2D sheets. Closer inspection of the cavity occupied by the tetraethylammonium cation revealed the advantageous positioning of the chlorine atoms from the chloranilate ligand to interact favorably with the cation. Indeed, the cavity appears to be an excellent fit for the tetraethylammonium cation, which can form C–H···O hydrogen-bonding interactions with the donor oxygen atoms of the anionic networks. It has previously been noted that the counterion used during the synthesis could act as a template in dictating the final topology in transition-metal benzoquinone-containing frameworks. It was therefore of interest to undertake a systematic study to explore the role of the cation as a template in the formation of lanthanide–chloranilate frameworks, specifically how the shape and size of the cation impact the topology and geometry of the lanthanide–chloranilate network.

elements.content: In this work, a range of potential countercations was used in the synthesis of lanthanide–chloranilate frameworks. The cations employed include tetrahedral-based aliphatic, aromatic, and mixed aliphatic–aromatic species. The effect of the lanthanide ion size on the coordination sphere and resultant topology was explored using the relatively large Ce­(III) and smaller Er­(III) centers.
elements.clean_text: In this work, a range of potential countercations was used in the synthesis of lanthanide-chloranilate frameworks. The cations employed include tetrahedral-based aliphatic, aromatic, and mixed aliphatic-aromatic species. The effect of the lanthanide ion size on the coordination sphere and resultant topology was explored using the relatively large Ce(III) and smaller Er(III) centers.

elements.content: The Er­(III) and Ce­(III) frameworks ( and ) were synthesized upon carefully layering a solution of chloranilic acid (H2can) and LiOAc·2H2O in acetone over a solution of the metal nitrate and the selected countercation salt in water. Within 3–7 days, the formation of dark purple crystals was observed in all reactions. The structures obtained in this study can be grouped into three categories: distorted neutral 2D (6,3) networks obtained using tetramethylammonium or tetrabutylammonium cations, anionic 3D diamond (dia) networks obtained using the 1-(diphenylmethyl)-pyridinium (DPMP+) or PPh4 + cations, and complex networks obtained with triphenylmethylphosphonium cations.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

The Er(III) and Ce(III) frameworks ( and ) were synthesized upon carefully layering a solution of chloranilic acid (H2can) and LiOAc⋅2H2O in acetone over a solution of the metal nitrate and the selected countercation salt in water. Within 3-7 days, the formation of dark purple crystals was observed in all reactions. The structures obtained in this study can be grouped into three categories: distorted neutral 2D (6,3) networks obtained using tetramethylammonium or tetrabutylammonium cations, anionic 3D diamond (dia) networks obtained using the 1-(diphenylmethyl)-pyridinium (DPMP+) or PPh4 + cations, and complex networks obtained with triphenylmethylphosphonium cations.

The use of tetralkylammonium cations, such as Me4N+ and Bu4N+, in the synthesis of Ce­(III) benzoquinone frameworks yielded the 2D (6,3) honeycomb sheet structure of composition [Ce2(can)3(H2O)6]·2H2O·3C3H6O (1) (). The formation of a neutral network with the absence of the countercation is in stark contrast with the use of tetraethylammonium, in which the lanthanide centers are linked to four symmetry-related lanthanide ions within an anionic network. Compound 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pbcm. The Ce­(III) center is coordinated by three chelating can2– ligands and three water molecules to yield a nine-coordinate metal center (a), which is linked by bridging chloranilate ligands to symmetry-related Ce­(III) centers within a neutral 2D network. The Ce­(III)–O bond lengths in 1 varies between 2.445 to 2.549 Å with Ce­(III)–OH2 bond lengths of 2.454 to 2.556 Å, which are consistent with previous Ce­(III) anilate structures. The coordination geometries around both unique Ce­(III) centers in 1 are capped square antiprisms, as determined using the SHAPE program (Table S4).
elements.clean_text:
Tetraalkylammonium Cations

The use of tetralkylammonium cations, such as Me4N+ and Bu4N+, in the synthesis of Ce(III) benzoquinone frameworks yielded the 2D (6,3) honeycomb sheet structure of composition [Ce2(can)3(H2O)6]⋅2H2O⋅3C3H6O (1) (). The formation of a neutral network with the absence of the countercation is in stark contrast with the use of tetraethylammonium, in which the lanthanide centers are linked to four symmetry-related lanthanide ions within an anionic network. Compound 1 crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pbcm. The Ce(III) center is coordinated by three chelating can2- ligands and three water molecules to yield a nine-coordinate metal center (a), which is linked by bridging chloranilate ligands to symmetry-related Ce(III) centers within a neutral 2D network. The Ce(III)-O bond lengths in 1 varies between 2.445 to 2.549 Å with Ce(III)-OH2 bond lengths of 2.454 to 2.556 Å, which are consistent with previous Ce(III) anilate structures. The coordination geometries around both unique Ce(III) centers in 1 are capped square antiprisms, as determined using the SHAPE program (Table S4).

elements.content: (1) Structure of [Ce2(can)3(H2O)6]·2H2O·3C3H6O (1) depicting (a) the coordination around Ce­(III) center, (b) the angles between the Ce­(III) centers within the network, (c) the distorted honeycomb lattice view along the c axis, and (d) the 2D network along the a axis, indicating the coplanar Ce­(III) centers. Atoms are depicted as follows: cerium (light blue), oxygen (red), chlorine (green), and carbon (black). Hydrogens have been omitted for clarity in panels b–d.

elements.content: The framework voids of this neutral network are occupied by acetone and water, the solvents from which the compound was crystallized. Instead of the “propeller-like” coordination of the can2– ligands at the metal center observed in transition-metal 2D hexagonal structures, the incorporation of the Ce­(III) ion results in the planes of two can2– ligands being almost perpendicular to the mean plane of the network, whereas the third can2– ligand is close to coplanar with the sheets (c). The angles at the three-connecting node deviate significantly from the 120° required to form a regular hexagonal network; the angles between Ce­(III) angles in 1 are 97, 98, and 164°, resulting in a herringbone pattern (b). As indicated in d, the Ce­(III) centers are coplanar. The thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of framework 1 indicates the loss of one acetone molecule between 25 and 52 °C, one water molecule between 52 and 120 °C, and two coordinated water molecules between 116 and 147 °C, before the framework decomposes above 325 °C (Figure S14). A similar distortion of the (6,3) network occurs in [Pr2(C6O4(CN)­Cl)3(DMF)6], which has recently been reported. In this structure, each Pr­(III) center is coordinated by three chlorocyananilato ligands and three DMF molecules.

Instead of the "propeller-like" coordination of the can2- ligands at the metal center observed in transition-metal 2D hexagonal structures, the incorporation of the Ce(III) ion results in the planes of two can2- ligands being almost perpendicular to the mean plane of the network, whereas the third can2- ligand is close to coplanar with the sheets (c). The angles at the three-connecting node deviate significantly from the 120° required to form a regular hexagonal network; the angles between Ce(III) angles in 1 are 97, 98, and 164°, resulting in a herringbone pattern (b). As indicated in d, the Ce(III) centers are coplanar. The thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of framework 1 indicates the loss of one acetone molecule between 25 and 52 °C, one water molecule between 52 and 120 °C, and two coordinated water molecules between 116 and 147 °C, before the framework decomposes above 325 °C (Figure S14). A similar distortion of the (6,3) network occurs in [Pr2(C6O4(CN)Cl)3(DMF)6], which has recently been reported. In this structure, each Pr(III) center is coordinated by three chlorocyananilato ligands and three DMF molecules.

elements.content: The compound [Er2(can)3(H2O)6]·2H2O·1.5C3H6O (2) was obtained when Er­(III) was used in the presence of alkyl ammonium Me4N+ and Bu4N+ cations to yield a structure that crystallized in the triclinic P1̅ space group (). As with [Ce2(can)3(H2O)6]·2H2O·3C3H6O (1), a (6,3) network is obtained. Although there is a contraction in the ionic radius upon going from Ce­(III) (r = 115 pm) to Er­(III) (r = 103 pm), the metal center is still nine-coordinate, with the coordination environment formed by three chelating can2– ligands and three coordinated water molecules to yield a neutral framework (a). The Er­(III)–O bond lengths for 2 are found within the range of 2.326(4) to 3.409(4) Å, whereas the three Er­(III)–OH2 bond lengths are 2.338(4), 2.356(3), and 2.364(3) Å. The coordination geometry around the Er­(III) center can be described as a hexagonal bipyramid from SHAPE calculations (Table S5).

elements.content: Structure of [Er2(can)3(H2O)6]·2H2O·1.5C3H6O (2) depicting (a) the coordination around the Er­(III) center, (b) the angles between the Er­(III) centers within the network (c) the brickwork lattice, and (d) an edge view of the 2D network. elements.content: The (6,3) network of 2 is significantly distorted from the ideal honeycomb-type network with angles between the Er­(III) centers of 94, 95, and 166° (b). The overall network has a brickwork pattern (c), in contrast with the herringbone pattern of 1, with the Er­(III) centers being coplanar within the network (d). A similar type of network has been observed in [Y2can3]·12H2O, [Pr2can3]·8CH3CH2OH, and [Er2(C6O4Br2)3(DMF)6]. The TGA of framework 2 indicates the loss of one acetone molecule below 93 °C, followed by the loss of two water molecules between 93 and 100 °C from within the pores of the framework (Figure S14). After a plateau, a mass loss corresponding to the liberation of three coordinated water molecules between 165 and 198 °C is observed before the framework decomposes above 340 °C.

elements.content: This investigation has provided another two examples of neutral (6,3) networks formed from the combination of lanthanide ions and chloranilate ligands. Although there are significant geometrical differences, as indicated by a structural comparison of 1 and 2, both structures possess the (6,3) net topology. It is interesting to compare the herringbone structure [Ce2(can)3(H2O)6]·2H2O·3C3H6O of 1 with the purely hydrated forms that have been reported by Robson et al. In Robson’s paper, the purely hydrated [Ce2(can)3(H2O)6]·12H2O structure has the (6,3) topology with a geometry that is much closer to the idealized (6,3) network structure (Figure S1). The loss of one water molecule, [Ce2(can)3(H2O)6]·11H2O, results in a slightly distorted network with the absence of the mirror symmetry. The geometry adopted by the (6,3) net would appear to result from the regular nine-coordinate metal center occupied by the three chelating ligands and the three solvent molecules. The solvent mixture of acetone and water impacts the relative location of the three water molecules and the three chelating chloranilate ligands bound to the metal center. The geometry of these lanthanide–chloranilate networks therefore appears to be very sensitive to factors such as solvent composition.

The geometry of these lanthanide-chloranilate networks therefore appears to be very sensitive to factors such as solvent composition.

elements.content: It is of note that the use of Et4N+ results exclusively in the formation of a square grid lattice, whereas the use of both smaller Me4N+ and larger Bu4N+ cations results in the formation of a 2D (6,3) distorted honeycomb structure. The close interaction of the tetraethylammonium cation with the can2– ligand is due to each of the eight methylene hydrogen atoms participating in a C–H···O hydrogen bond with the oxygen atoms in the can2– ligand. The perfect alignment of the tetraethylammonium cation with the oxygen atoms of the can2– ligand is likely the strong driving force toward the formation of a square grid lattice. The use of either smaller or larger alkyl ammonium cations detracts from the favorable interactions possible with the tetraethylammonium cation, thus removing the driving focus for the formation of a square grid lattice. Given these results, it is unlikely that the small size of the alkyl ammonium salts has a large role in templating the formation of the distorted (6,3) nets. The pores within the distorted (6,3) nets with dimensions of 11.4 × 17.770 Å (for 1) and 8.689 × 17.285 Å (for 2) are mismatched with the alkyl ammonium salts, which have diameters of 5.132 to 5.152 Å for Et4N+ and 10.025 to 10.217 Å for Bu4N+, preventing strong intermolecular interactions from forming between the framework structure and the alkyl ammonium salt.

elements.content: Three cations with aromatic rings, 1-(diphenylmethyl)-pyridinium (DPMP+), PPh3Me+, and PPh4 +, were chosen to investigate the effect of bulky, relatively rigid cations upon the formation and structure of lanthanide–chloranilate frameworks. The slow diffusion of the deprotonated chloranilate ligand into a solution of Ce­(NO3)3·6H2O or Er­(NO3)3·6H2O and the DPMP+ countercation at room temperature yielded (DPMP)­[Ce­(can)2(H2O)]·H2O·C3H6O (3) and (DPMP)­[Er­(can)2] (4), respectively, as large purple block crystals after ∼3 days.
elements.clean_text:
Cations with Aromatic Rings

Three cations with aromatic rings, 1-(diphenylmethyl)-pyridinium (DPMP+), PPh3Me+, and PPh4 +, were chosen to investigate the effect of bulky, relatively rigid cations upon the formation and structure of lanthanide-chloranilate frameworks. The slow diffusion of the deprotonated chloranilate ligand into a solution of Ce(NO3)3⋅6H2O or Er(NO3)3⋅6H2O and the DPMP+ countercation at room temperature yielded (DPMP)[Ce(can)2(H2O)]⋅H2O⋅C3H6O (3) and (DPMP)[Er(can)2] (4), respectively, as large purple block crystals after ~3 days.

elements.content: Compound 3 crystallizes in the triclinic space group P1̅ and features a nine-coordinate Ce­(III) center bound to four chelating can2– ligands and one water molecule. Ce–O bond distances from the chloranilate ligand are in the range of 2.488(2) to 2.501(2) Å, whereas a longer Ce–O bond length of 2.588(4) Å is observed from the bound water molecule The coordination geometry about the Ce­(III) center was found to be a capped square antiprism through SHAPE calculations (Table S4).

Ce-O bond distances from the chloranilate ligand are in the range of 2.488(2) to 2.501(2) Å, whereas a longer Ce-O bond length of 2.588(4) Å is observed from the bound water molecule The coordination geometry about the Ce(III) center was found to be a capped square antiprism through SHAPE calculations (Table S4).

elements.content: The Ce­(III) ions and can2– ligands are linked to form 2D (6,3) networks that are then further linked by bridging chloranilate ligands to yield a 3D anionic network with the diamond (dia) topology (a). The incompatibility of the nine-coordinate metal center with the ideal tetrahedral geometry results in the distortion of the framework away from the ideal diamond geometry (b). The distortion from ideal tetrahedral angles of 109.5° around the Ce­(III) node results in angles between Ce­(III) centers of 76, 89, 103, 115, 121, and 134°. The DPMP+ cation, needed for charge balance, sits perfectly within the cavity of the adamantane unit (a), with multiple intermolecular interactions between the cation and framework (b). Offset π–π polarization exists between the aromatic rings of the cation with the can2– ligand (d π –π = 3.898 Å). Several hydrogen-bonding interactions are present, including a C–H···O interaction between the water molecule on the Ce­(III) and the hydrogen on the central carbon of DPMP (d CH···O = 3.301(5) Å) and a C–H···O interaction between the aromatic hydrogens on DPMP+ and the oxygen atoms of can2– (d CH···O = 3.200(5), 3.318(4), 3.536(5) Å). The TGA of 3 indicates the loss of two molecules of water between 25 and 118 °C before the decomposition of the framework above 390 °C (Figure S15).

elements.content: Structure of (DPMP)­[Ce­(can)2] (3) depicting (a) the anionic framework with the diamond topology viewed along the a axis with the DPMP+ cation depicted in purple and (b) an adamantane unit with the intermolecular interactions of DPMP+ with the framework, as depicted through striped black and white connections. The hydrogens have been omitted for clarity in panel a. Atoms are depicted as follows: carbon (black in can2–, purple in DPMP+), cerium (light blue), oxygen (red), chlorine (green), nitrogen (dark blue), and hydrogen (light pink).

elements.content: In a similar manner to (DPMP)­[Ce­(can)2(H2O)]·H2O·C3H6O (3), the anionic framework of (DPMP)­[Er­(can)2] (4) also exhibits the dia topology; however, it crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c and contains an eight-coordinate Er­(III) center, which is bound to four chelating can2– ligands (Figure S2a). The Er–O bond lengths are 2.316(5) and 2.353(3) Å, which is within the expected range for a Er­(III) to oxygen bond. The coordination geometry about the Er­(III) center is a square antiprism, as determined using the SHAPE program. The exclusion of the coordinated water molecule in 4 reflects the smaller ionic radius of Er­(III) compared with Ce­(III).

The Er-O bond lengths are 2.316(5) and 2.353(3) Å, which is within the expected range for a Er(III) to oxygen bond. The coordination geometry about the Er(III) center is a square antiprism, as determined using the SHAPE program. The exclusion of the coordinated water molecule in 4 reflects the smaller ionic radius of Er(III) compared with Ce(III).

elements.content: The diamond net in 4 more closely resembles the geometry of the ideal diamond net than the anionic net in 3, with angles between Ce­(III) centers of 75, 107, 110, 110 128, and 128° (Figure S2b). The DPMP+ counterion, which is required for charge balance, was unable to be resolved in the crystal structure due to significant disorder. A solvent mask was therefore applied, whereupon 312 e– were removed, corresponding to the presence of the DPMP+ counterion with acetone and water solvate molecules within the intraframework voids. It would seem likely that the DPMP+ is located in the adamantane cavity and interacts with the framework in a similar manner to that observed in 3. The TGA of framework 4 indicates the loss of one water molecule between 25 and 230 °C, followed by decomposition above 325 °C. The small mass loss of 2.1% reflects the lack of pore space present due to the close interaction of DPMP+ with the framework.

elements.content: A diamond-type network was also obtained upon reaction of Ce­(NO3)3·6H2O with the PPh4 + cation to yield (PPh4)­[Ce­(can)2(H2O)] (5), which crystallized in the monoclinic space group C2/c. The Ce­(III) center is nine-coordinate with four can2– ligands and one coordinated water molecule. The Ce–O bond lengths observed in 5 from the chloranilate ligand are within the range of 2.491(2) to 2.528(2) Å. In an analogous manner to 3, the Ce–O bond length of 2.545(2) Å to the coordinated water molecule is slightly longer than the Ce–O bond lengths from the chloranilate ligand. The coordination geometry about the Ce­(III) center in 5 was determined to be a tricapped trigonal prism using the SHAPE program (Table S4).

elements.content: As for frameworks 3 and 4, a cation, in this case PPh4 +, is required for charge balance. The cation sits neatly within the adamantane voids (a). Despite the presence of a nine-coordinate metal center, the anionic [Ce­(can)2(H2O)] – framework exhibits only relatively little distortion from the ideal diamond net, which can be appreciated by the inspection of the adamantane-type unit depicted in b. The angles between the Ce­(III) centers in the network are 91, 91, 115, 115, 118, and 122°. Several intermolecular interactions exist between the PPh4 + cation and the can2– ligands of the framework structure, including hydrogen-bonding interactions between the aromatic hydrogens on the PPh4 + with the oxygen of the can2– ligand (d CH···O = 3.449(4), 3.592(3) Å) (b) and a Cl−π interaction (d Cl−π = 3.986 Å). The TGA of framework 5 indicates the loss of one water molecule from the framework between 25 and 56 °C, followed by the loss of two water molecules between 56 and 114 °C (Figure S15), indicating the likely possibility of water molecules within the cavities of the framework. The framework decomposes above 280 °C.

elements.content: The synthesis of an Er­(III) chloranilate diamond network with PPh4 + was unsuccessful, with only a neutral coordination polymer of composition Er2(can)3(H2O) x obtained (Figure S10). The compound is identical to a previously reported structure (refcode: XAXBEG). The failure to form a diamond-like network for Er­(III) when PPh4 + is present may reflect the fact that the [Er­(can)2]− adamantane cavity is smaller than the corresponding [Ce­(can)2]− cavity owing to the lanthanide contraction from Ce­(III) to Er­(III), thus preventing the accommodation of the bulky PPh4 + cation. Alternatively, the formation of Er2(can)3(H2O) n ·xH2O under the conditions employed may simply indicate the stability of the neutral coordination polymer.

The failure to form a diamond-like network for Er(III) when PPh4 + is present may reflect the fact that the [Er(can)2]- adamantane cavity is smaller than the corresponding [Ce(can)2]- cavity owing to the lanthanide contraction from Ce(III) to Er(III), thus preventing the accommodation of the bulky PPh4 + cation. Alternatively, the formation of Er2(can)3(H2O) n ⋅xH2O under the conditions employed may simply indicate the stability of the neutral coordination polymer.

elements.content: To the best of our knowledge, the only previous example of an anionic diamond-type network, involving lanthanide–benzoquinoid ligands, is a [Y­(can)2]− framework for which the oxonium ion serves as the countercation despite the availability of triethylammonium in the reaction mixture. The overall structure has a pleasing tetragonal symmetry. A diamond-type network of composition Th­(can)2(H2O)2·4H2O has also been obtained by linking metal centers by bridging chloranilate ligands. This network, in which the Th­(IV) centers are 10-coordinate is a grossly distorted diamond-type structure with two of the coordination sites occupied by water molecules.

The overall structure has a pleasing tetragonal symmetry. A diamond-type network of composition Th(can)2(H2O)2⋅4H2O has also been obtained by linking metal centers by bridging chloranilate ligands. This network, in which the Th(IV) centers are 10-coordinate is a grossly distorted diamond-type structure with two of the coordination sites occupied by water molecules.

elements.content: This final section considers the effect of the Ph3PMe+ cation on the type of network formed. The reaction of Ce­(NO3)3·6H2O with H2can, in the presence of the Ph3PMe+ cation, result in the formation of an anionic 3D dimensional structure, (PPh3Me)­[Ce­(can)2(H2O)] (6), with noq topology (). This compound crystallized in the monoclinic space group P21/n. The Ce­(III) center is nine-coordinate with four chelating can2– ligands and one water molecule bound to the metal center in an irregular coordination environment (a). The Ce–O bond lengths in compound 6 from the chloranilate ligand to the Ce­(III) are within the range of 2.468(5) to 2.625(4) Å, whereas the Ce–O bond lengths to the coordinated water molecules are 2.540(6) and 2.637(4) Å. Two of the unique Ce­(III) centers, Ce(1) and Ce(2), feature a capped square antiprism coordination geometry, whereas Ce(3) is a tricapped trigonal prism. It is of note that the minimum value from the SHAPE program for Ce(2) of 1.199 for the capped square antiprism geometry is only slightly less than the value of 1.202 obtained for the muffin geometry (Table S6).

The Ce-O bond lengths in compound 6 from the chloranilate ligand to the Ce(III) are within the range of 2.468(5) to 2.625(4) Å, whereas the Ce-O bond lengths to the coordinated water molecules are 2.540(6) and 2.637(4) Å. Two of the unique Ce(III) centers, Ce(1) and Ce(2), feature a capped square antiprism coordination geometry, whereas Ce(3) is a tricapped trigonal prism. It is of note that the minimum value from the SHAPE program for Ce(2) of 1.199 for the capped square antiprism geometry is only slightly less than the value of 1.202 obtained for the muffin geometry (Table S6).

elements.content: The PPh3Me+ cations are located in the voids of both the four-membered and five-membered circuits, as indicated in c. Despite close interactions between the framework and the cations, there is positional disorder in several of the phenyl rings of the PPh3Me+ cations. Hydrogen-bonding interactions are present between the H2O molecule coordinated to the Ce­(III) metal center and an aromatic hydrogen on PPh3Me+ (d C–H···O = 3.86(3) Å) and between both the methyl group and aromatic hydrogens on the PPh3Me+ cation and the oxygen atoms of the can2– ligand (d C–H···O = 3.16(2), 3.68(1), 3.77(1), 3.530(9), 3.341(7), 3.799(8) Å and d CH3···O = 3.321(7), 3.769(7) Å). A significant halogen–hydrogen interaction between a Cl atom of a can2– ligand and an aromatic hydrogen of PPh3Me+ (d Cl···HC = 3.386(7) Å) is also apparent. Interactions involving the aromatic rings of the cation and the can2– ligand include π–π stacking (or π-system polarization from one aromatic ring to the other) from a phenyl ring of Ph3PMe+ to can2– (d π –π = 3.498 Å), Cl−π interaction from the chlorine atom in can2– to a phenyl ring of Ph3PMe (d Cl−π = 3.504 Å), and a CH−π interaction from an aromatic hydrogen on PPh3Me+ to the aromatic ring in the can2– ligand (d CH−π = 3.845 Å). The TGA of framework 6 indicates the loss of two water molecules between 25 and 100 °C from within the pores of the framework (Figure S16). The coordinated water molecule is lost between 106 and 187 °C before decomposition of 6 is observed above 370 °C.

elements.content: To the best of our knowledge, there have only been two previous reports of structures with noq topology. Both structures are Cd­(CN)2(H2O) coordination network solids (CSD refcodes: LATCIS and WILRIS) with diethyl ether or dipropyl ether solvent molecules in the intraframework spaces. In both structures, the noq topology is formed by alternating four-coordinate and six-coordinate metal centers.

In both structures, the noq topology is formed by alternating four-coordinate and six-coordinate metal centers.

elements.content: The reaction of Er­(NO3)3·6H2O with H2can, in the presence of PPh3Me+, yielded crystals of composition (PPh3Me)2[Er2(can)4]·H2O (7) that crystallized in the monoclinic P21/c space group. The Er­(III) center is nine-coordinate with four can2– ligands and one water molecule. A relatively wide range of Er–O bond lengths is observed in 7 within the range of 2.268(2) to 2.424(2) Å. The particularly short Er–O bond length of 2.268(2) Å may be due to the greater planarity of Er–O bonds relative to the chloranilate ligand, where the other coordinated chloranilate ligands are bent slightly out of the plane, possibly due to steric effects. The coordination geometry about the Er­(III) center can be described as a triangular dodecahedron, which was the most appropriate fit determined from the SHAPE program. Full details of the SHAPE analysis for 7 can be found in Figure S5.

elements.content: Despite the presence of the nine-coordinate Er­(III) center, the structure obtained with Er­(III) and PPh3Me+ is not isostructural to that with Ce­(III). This is likely attributed to the shorter bond M­(III)–O lengths of Er (Er–O = 2.268 to 2.424 Å) when compared with Ce (Ce–O = 2.468 to 2.625 Å) and the shorter MM distance in 7 (Er···Er = 8.543 Å) when compared with 6 (Ce···Ce = 8.954 Å), as measured through the bridging can2– ligand. The shorter dimensions of the framework result in the inclusion of only two PPh3Me+ cations instead of three PPh3Me+, as in framework 6.

The shorter dimensions of the framework result in the inclusion of only two PPh3Me+ cations instead of three PPh3Me+, as in framework 6.

elements.content: The framework within 7 consists of parallel 2D sheets with four- and five-membered circuits (a), which are linked to each other by bridging chloranilate anions, which results in the formation of a seven-membered circuit and the generation of a 3D anionic network. Two unique Er environments exist in the structure; the first Er­(III) site exists entirely within the 2D sheet, whereas the second Er­(III) site serves to link the 2D sheets to form the 3D structure (a). The PPh3Me+ cation is mostly located within the five-membered circuits in the framework and is involved in multiple intermolecular interactions with the framework structure (b). These include hydrogen-bonding interactions between the aromatic hydrogen atoms and the oxygen atoms of can2– (d C–H···O = 3.486(4), 3.555(5), 3.603(4), 3.619(4) Å). Interactions involving the π aromatic ring systems of PPh3Me+ and the can2– ligand include π–π polarization between adjacent aromatic rings (d π –π = 3.554 and 3.626 Å), Cl−π interactions between can2– and the phenyl ring of the PPh3Me+ cation (d Cl−π = 3.920 Å), and CH−π interactions between the methyl group of PPh3Me and can2– (d CH−π = 3.731 Å). The underlying topology of framework 7 was determined using TOPOS and Systre and consists of a 4,4′-c net with point symbol {4.52.73}­{4.53.72} and a symmetry of P21/c, which matches the crystallographic space group. It appears that this topology has not been previously identified. The TGA of framework 7 indicates the loss of one water molecule between 25 and 302 °C, followed by decomposition above 380 °C (Figure S16).

elements.content: This work has described a variety of structures in which lanthanide ions are linked by chloranilate dianions within neutral 2D [M2can3(H2O)6] networks or anionic networks of general composition [M­(can)2]−. In all structures considered, the lanthanide ions are eight- or nine-coordinate, and the chloranilate features a bidentate coordination mode. The combination of the lanthanide ion with chloranilic acid in a 1:2 proportion, in the presence of a weak base (lithium acetate), yielded either a 2D neutral network or an anionic network depending on the identity of the cation employed. When the tetraalkylammonium cations, NMe4 + or NBu4 +, are used, the additional chloranilate anion is not included in the network, resulting in neutral 2D networks with (6,3) topology. These results suggest that the interactions between an anionic [M­(can)2]− network and the cations NMe4 + or NBu4 + fail to produce a structure that is able to compete with the stability of the neutral network. It is interesting to compare the behavior of these cations with that of NEt4 +, which can promote the formation of an isostructural series in which the cation neatly occupies a cavity bound by eight chlorine atoms. The complementary interaction involving multiple equivalent C–H···O hydrogen bonds provides a very stable structural arrangement.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

This work has described a variety of structures in which lanthanide ions are linked by chloranilate dianions within neutral 2D [M2can3(H2O)6] networks or anionic networks of general composition [M(can)2]-. In all structures considered, the lanthanide ions are eight- or nine-coordinate, and the chloranilate features a bidentate coordination mode. The combination of the lanthanide ion with chloranilic acid in a 1:2 proportion, in the presence of a weak base (lithium acetate), yielded either a 2D neutral network or an anionic network depending on the identity of the cation employed. When the tetraalkylammonium cations, NMe4 + or NBu4 +, are used, the additional chloranilate anion is not included in the network, resulting in neutral 2D networks with (6,3) topology. These results suggest that the interactions between an anionic [M(can)2]- network and the cations NMe4 + or NBu4 + fail to produce a structure that is able to compete with the stability of the neutral network. It is interesting to compare the behavior of these cations with that of NEt4 +, which can promote the formation of an isostructural series in which the cation neatly occupies a cavity bound by eight chlorine atoms. The complementary interaction involving multiple equivalent C-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds provides a very stable structural arrangement.

elements.content: When the cation used possesses aromatic rings, that is, DPMP+, PPh3Me+, or PPh4 +, the formation of the anionic network appears to be favored, except when Er­(III) is combined with PPh4 +. In these cases, multiple interactions, including those involving the π electrons from aromatic rings, can promote the incorporation of the cation within the voids of the anionic network.

elements.content: The breadth of structures that have been identified for lanthanide–chloranilate framework materials reflects the large number of factors, besides cation choice, that impact the topology and geometry of the network. One of the most important factors relates to the high coordination numbers of the metal ion. With coordination numbers typically of eight or nine, the coordination environment of the metal center can show much greater variation than that seen with octahedral complexes. The relative positions of the chloranilate ligands and coordinated solvent molecules is a major factor governing the geometry of not only the metal center but also the resulting network. Energetically, one would imagine very little difference between a number of different coordination geometries, particularly when the interaction between the metal and the ligand has strong ionic character. Given such circumstances it is not surprising that factors such as lanthanide ion size and solvent mixtures could play an important structure-directing role.

elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Considerations

All chemicals were used as obtained and without further purification. 1-(Diphenylmethyl)-pyridinium bromide (DPMPBr) was synthesized according to literature procedures. Microanalyses were carried out at the Chemical Analysis Facility at Macquarie University, NSW, Australia.

elements.content: A solution of chloranilic acid (0.10 mmol) and lithium acetate (0.20 mmol) in acetone (5 mL) was layered above a solution of Ce­(NO3)3·6H2O (21.7 mg, 0.050 mmol) with either NMe4Br or NBu4Br (0.50 mmol) in water (3 mL). The layered solutions were left for 3–7 days to crystallize by diffusion, giving purple plate-like crystals. The purple crystals were washed with acetone until the filtrate was colorless (∼3 × 3 mL) and dried in air to yield compound 1 (13.3 mg, 42%). Elemental Analysis: Found C, 33.74; H, 4.59; N, 0.00%; Calculated for C18H12Ce2Cl6O18·8.88C3H6O·3.55H2O: C, 33.74; H, 4.59; N, 0.00%. FTIR (ATR): 2957 (C–H stretch), 2872 (C–H stretch), 1697 (CO stretch), 1478 (C–H bend), 1373 (C–H bend), 994 (CC bend), 841 (C–C bend) cm–1.

A solution of chloranilic acid (0.10 mmol) and lithium acetate (0.20 mmol) in acetone (5 mL) was layered above a solution of Ce(NO3)3⋅6H2O (21.7 mg, 0.050 mmol) with PPh4Br (209.6 mg, 0.50 mmol) in water (3 mL), with any undissolved solids dissolved in a further 1 to 2 mL of methanol. The layered solutions were left for 3-7 days to crystallize by diffusion, giving dark-purple block crystals. The purple crystals were washed with acetone until the filtrate was colorless (~3 × 3 mL) and dried in air to yield compound 3 (31.0 mg, 68%). Elemental Analysis: Found C, 44.54; H, 3.08; N, 0.00%; Calculated for C36H22CeCl4O9P⋅0.2C3H6O⋅3.55H2O: C, 44.54; H, 3.09; N, 0.00%. FTIR (ATR): 3076 (C-H stretch), 2979 (C-H stretch), 1669 (CO stretch), 1468 (C-H bend), 1371 (C-H bend), 1107 (C-O stretch), 995 (CC bend), 843 (C-C bend) cm-1.

elements.content: Purple crystals were directly transferred from their mother liquor to the protective oil before being mounted on a XtaLAB Synergy, Dualflex, HyPix diffractometer employing mirror monochromated Mo Kα or Cu Kα radiation generated from a microfocus sealed X-ray tube. Data were collected at 100.0(2) K. Data reduction and absorption correction were carried out using the CrysAlisPro software. All structures were solved using direct methods with SHELXT and refined with SHELXL within the Olex2 graphical interface. All non-hydrogen atoms in the asymmetric unit were modeled with anisotropic displacement parameters. A riding atom model was used for all hydrogen atoms.
elements.clean_text:
Crystallography

Purple crystals were directly transferred from their mother liquor to the protective oil before being mounted on a XtaLAB Synergy, Dualflex, HyPix diffractometer employing mirror monochromated Mo Kα or Cu Kα radiation generated from a microfocus sealed X-ray tube. Data were collected at 100.0(2) K. Data reduction and absorption correction were carried out using the CrysAlisPro software. All structures were solved using direct methods with SHELXT and refined with SHELXL within the Olex2 graphical interface. All non-hydrogen atoms in the asymmetric unit were modeled with anisotropic displacement parameters. A riding atom model was used for all hydrogen atoms.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on an XtaLAB Synergy diffractometer employing Cu Kα at λ = 1.5418 Å. Samples were loaded as powder into Lindemann glass capillary tubes, and patterns were collected at 100 K. PXRD patterns from single-crystal structures were calculated using Mercury v.3.10.
elements.clean_text:
Powder X-ray Diffraction

Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on an XtaLAB Synergy diffractometer employing Cu Kα at λ = 1.5418 Å. Samples were loaded as powder into Lindemann glass capillary tubes, and patterns were collected at 100 K. PXRD patterns from single-crystal structures were calculated using Mercury v.3.10.

elements.content:
TGA was measured on a Mettler TGA/SDTA851 instrument using 5–10 mg of sample from 25–400 °C using an aluminum pan and heated at a rate of 5 °C/min under a nitrogen atmosphere.

Infrared Spectroscopy

Infrared spectra were collected on a Bruker Alpha ATR instrument. A small amount (∼2 mg) was placed on the ATR crystal, and the data were collected using 16 scans with 4 cm–1 resolution over the range of 4000–400 cm–1.

cln_elements.content: The framework voids of this neutral network are occupied by acetone and water, the solvents from which the compound was crystallized. Instead of the “propeller-like” coordination of the can2– ligands at the metal center observed in transition-metal 2D hexagonal structures, the incorporation of the Ce­(III) ion results in the planes of two can2– ligands being almost perpendicular to the mean plane of the network, whereas the third can2– ligand is close to coplanar with the sheets (c). The angles at the three-connecting node deviate significantly from the 120° required to form a regular hexagonal network; the angles between Ce­(III) angles in 1 are 97, 98, and 164°, resulting in a herringbone pattern (b). As indicated in d, the Ce­(III) centers are coplanar. The thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of framework 1 indicates the loss of one acetone molecule between 25 and 52 °C, one water molecule between 52 and 120 °C, and two coordinated water molecules between 116 and 147 °C, before the framework decomposes above 325 °C (Figure S14). A similar distortion of the (6,3) network occurs in [Pr2(C6O4(CN)­Cl)3(DMF)6], which has recently been reported. In this structure, each Pr­(III) center is coordinated by three chlorocyananilato ligands and three DMF molecules.

Instead of the "propeller-like" coordination of the can2- ligands at the metal center observed in transition-metal 2D hexagonal structures, the incorporation of the Ce(III) ion results in the planes of two can2- ligands being almost perpendicular to the mean plane of the network, whereas the third can2- ligand is close to coplanar with the sheets (c). The angles at the three-connecting node deviate significantly from the 120° required to form a regular hexagonal network; the angles between Ce(III) angles in 1 are 97, 98, and 164°, resulting in a herringbone pattern (b). As indicated in d, the Ce(III) centers are coplanar. The thermal gravimetric analysis (TGA) of framework 1 indicates the loss of one acetone molecule between 25 and 52 °C, one water molecule between 52 and 120 °C, and two coordinated water molecules between 116 and 147 °C, before the framework decomposes above 325 °C (Figure S14). A similar distortion of the (6,3) network occurs in [Pr2(C6O4(CN)Cl)3(DMF)6], which has recently been reported. In this structure, each Pr(III) center is coordinated by three chlorocyananilato ligands and three DMF molecules.

data.type: loss of two coordinated water molecules
